Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this study is to collect network data from an online drug market to examine its structure and the processes through which it forms. The focus is to evaluate 1) how the market grows, behaves, and changes over time and 2) how the market reacts to law enforcement efforts. The project aims to shed new light on criminals' use of technology and to track changes in drug dealers' distribution tactics, drawing from network theories and theories of criminal coordination. Drug procurement through online drug markets and encrypted Internet services is increasing. Scholars and policy makers are calling for more research on drug access via the Internet through encrypted online drug marketplaces.

Encrypted virtual criminal networks are an ideal case to study the impact of emergent technologies on the organization of real world crime. By limiting the risk of detection, anonymizing technologies provide a unique medium for criminal groups to coordinate offending. Deterrence strategies assume that most crime is committed by a few key actors, who sometimes recruit others to participate. Crucial to this understanding is that crime is a group-level phenomenon, where 1) crime groups are fluid, and can be better understood as a network of criminal affiliations, and 2) only a few offenders direct network activities and are responsible for most offending. In this regard, criminal coordination refers to recruitment and participation in a network of criminal affiliations, even when participants may not consider themselves to be members of a crime group. This makes network analysis ideal to understand how disruption efforts affect crime groups' behavior and coordination, especially when the network takes the shape of a market, because it treats crime groups as a series of affiliations, rather than as a stable entity. The study will employ network methodologies to answer two broad research questions: (1) How do online criminal networks organize and what actor characteristics drive transactional ties? (2) How do online criminal networks behave over time and react to potential deterrence strategies? Findings will generate knowledge about new forms of criminal organization, as well as drug enforcement and prevention agencies, and will shed light on the relational dynamics that sustain and facilitate the growth of online crime networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Online Criminal Drug Networks (PI: Dana Haynie) is a three-year funded project representing the first longitudinal network data collection effort of an active online drug market located on the darknet. In 2017, an interdisciplinary team of sociologists and computer scientists collected data from three large darknet drug markets to assess (1) assess its network structure, (2) examine market operations, and (3) gauge how the markets react to disruption. The investigators designed data scrapers to crawl information from each of these markets and reconstruct structure. Network models of roughly 50,000 drug transactions over the course of three years were constructed.

The project proceeded over three phases:

Stage 1 (Data scraping): In the first year, the team designed a web crawler to pull information from the three markets. The team then collaborated to build a data scraper to comb through the HTML files to record information on sale characteristics, vendor characteristics, and buyer characteristics.

Stage 2 (Data analysis): In the second year, we built network models of the darknet drug markets and presented preliminary results at Washington D.C. at the Coalition for National Science Funding. We collaborated with the Drug Enforcement Agency to discuss possible strategies. We began compiling our analyses into scientific reports for publication.

Stage 3 (Reporting results): During a third extension year, we reported results at national academic conferences and submitted our research to academic journals. At the end of this year, we received funding for a follow up darknet network study that uses machine learning and natural language processing to assess how market actors build trust in an anonymous and high-risk exchange environment. This rich qualitative data along with further network collection will inform further papers and policy reports on darknet drug trafficking.

Principal findings from this project reveal that the darknet drug networks studied have unique structural properties. Online drug networks are highly clustered, with strong community structure coalescing around high reputation vendors (published in Journal of Quantitative Criminology). Thus, trade on darknet drug markets are largely determined by reputational knowledge of vendors selling drugs. The high preferential attachment to high reputation vendors yields a scale-free network structure that is vulnerable to deletions of highly connected vendors, but somewhat less vulnerable to comparable offline drug trafficking networks (published in Social Networks). Consequently, while online drug markets are vulnerable to disruptions, they are less vulnerable than most criminal networks. We also find that the structure of darknet trade networks helps to ensure cooperation and shape prices in the early stages of market development where reputational information is scarce.

The team also considered network reactivity in terms of potential to disrupt online drug markets. Overall, we find that conventional policing strategies are largely ineffective for curbing darknet drug trade. Instead reputational-based and diffuse policing strategies are more effective and less costly than conventional policing strategies. Agent-based simulations suggest that profit-oriented criminal networks are quicker to recover from disruptions than robust networks (published in Criminology). Consequently, even though darknet drug markets sustain substantial damage from policing interventions, they are also quick to recover. Additional empirically grounded simulations indicate that darknet drug markets are most vulnerable to non-traditional policing interventions that damage vendors’ reputations in the early stages of market development (forthcoming in PLOS One).

Ongoing research examines the impact of the network structure of darknet drug markets for the frequency of drug trade and the pricing of illegal goods. Findings indicate that clusters of illegal drug trade establish trust between market actors in the high-risk stages of market development. Further, clustering and patterns of repeated exchange influence the prices vendors set for illegal drugs. Network dynamics within darknet drug markets, therefore, appear to be critical for sustaining trade and assigning prices to illegal drugs.

Broader Impacts of this study are multi-disciplinary, and contribute to knowledge in the fields of Criminology, Sociology, Computer Science, Cybersecurity, Public Health and Criminal Justice policy.  We empirically characterize the internal dynamics that sustain and promote new forms of crime and provide insight into the effectiveness of policing strategies for deterring this new form of crime.  We also identify how co-offenders cooperate and establish trust in high-risk environments with minimal reputational knowledge. Findings have been applied to understand digital interaction on darknet networks and data have been used by consultant Srinivasan Parthasarathy to develop duplicate account detection algorithms in the Tor network. Findings from this project illustrate how new anonymizing technologies can facilitate illegal activities in cyber-space. This allows us to empirically assess the properties of the criminal networks on the darknet to evaluate which disruption techniques are most effective at constraining trade. Thus, we assess and develop policing strategies for deterring darknet drug trade. This project also offered insight to the behaviors of one underexplored pathway contributing to current drug crises, namely the opioid epidemic.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2020
Modified by: Dana L Haynie

In 2017, an interdisciplinary team of sociologists and computer scientists collected data from three large darknet drug markets to assess (1) assess its network structure, (2) examine market operations, and (3) gauge how the markets react to disruption. The investigators designed data scrapers to crawl information from each of these markets and reconstruct structure. Network models of roughly 50,000 drug transactions over the course of three years were constructed. The project proceeded over three phases: Stage 1 (Data scraping): In the first year, the team designed a web crawler to pull information from the three markets. The team then collaborated to build a data scraper to comb through the HTML files to record information on sale characteristics, vendor characteristics, and buyer characteristics. Stage 2 (Data analysis): In the second year, we built network models of the darknet drug markets and presented preliminary results at Washington D.C. at the Coalition for National Science Funding. We collaborated with the Drug Enforcement Agency to discuss possible strategies. We began compiling our analyses into scientific reports for publication. At the end of this year, we received funding for a follow up darknet network study that uses machine learning and natural language processing to assess how market actors build trust in an anonymous and high-risk exchange environment. Findings have been applied to understand digital interaction on darknet networks and data have been used by consultant Srinivasan Parthasarathy to develop duplicate account detection algorithms in the Tor network. This allows us to empirically assess the properties of the criminal networks on the darknet to evaluate which disruption techniques are most effective at constraining trade. Thus, we assess and develop policing strategies for deterring darknet drug trade.
